LOBL.content: untranslatability will not stop the procession, cortège, over the border of another language, into the language of another
text lives on only if it lives on (sur-vit), it lives on only if it is at once (hama) translatable and untranslatable, Übersetzung and “translation” overcome

totally translatable disappears as body, writing, text, language; totally untranslatable dies immediately > thus, triumphant translation neither life nor death of text, only or already its living on, neither lives nor dies

triumphant translation is a life after death, same goes for writing, trace, mark: neither lives nor dies, lives on, “starts” w/ living on (testament, iterability, restance, crypt, detachment that lifts the strictures of the “living” rectio or direction of “author” not drowned at edge of his text)
relative synonymy Derrida seeks to produce btwn triumph of life & arrêt de mort

AF.content: in response to Derrida’s statement that L’Un se garde de l’autre pour se faire violence can only be said/ thus archived so economically in French, Bennington wonders if Derrida committed violent election of the one: Derrida says he never spoke of absolute untranslatibility, and that his affirmation of idiomaticity is always one of deferral & impurity [both were ironic?]

A.content: shibboleth effect, untranslatability (essential incompleteness of translation), borders of untranslatability w/in original language itself

PAS.content: Blanchot writes in a way where untranslatability closes off nothing (ne ferme rien), where Witz [see p. 50], slavish and commonplace, finds itself sovereignly thwarted (déjouée)

S.content: that one can only think in German is a half-asleep tautology (confirmed by ideas of untranslatability of Sein, Denken, Geist)
Geschick, Schickliche, Schicksal, Geschichte, untranslatable because this chain is deployed in its own idiomatic mission of history

FSW.content: it is the materiality of signifier that is relinquished in translation > when materiality is reinstated, translation becomes poetry
since materiality of signifier constitutes idiom of dream scene, dreams are untranslatable
for Freud, wrong to think simple translation can occur from unconscious to conscious, presupposes immobile master text > unconscious consists of archives always already transcriptions

SH.content: untranslatability connected w/ difficult passage (no pasarán), aporia, that isolates one poetic language from another (& multiplicity w/in language) > also ce pas impossible
shibboleth resists translation due to that w/in it that cuts nonsignifying difference in body, mark, written, oral
every untranslatable space, pause, calls for and provokes translation > shibboleth merges completely w/ translation in its essential dimension

TB.content: untranslatability less to do w/ adequation than unique occurrence of a performative of force
sacred text is transferability making its translation untranslatable
sacred text (absolute text): pas de sens (not poverty of meaning, but no meaning that would be itself) > sacred text surrenders itself to translation; commands right away the translation it refuses
translation: task of pure limit, an infinite labor to rejoin (doesn’t exclude gradations, virtuality, interval & in-btwn) > can one quote a signature?

Gii.content: Heidegger employs idiomatic untranslatability of opposition btwn geistig/geistlich to withdraw Gedicht (“site”) of Trakl from Platonic tradition, w/ its opposition aisthēton/noeton (“sensible” material/“intelligible” spirituality), and from Christian opposition spiritual/temporal

DST.content: is it a law? Derrida’s choosing or compulsion to introduce a translation of an untranslatable [re: désistement]
tie thinking of untranslatable idiom to logic of double constraint: one must avoid avoiding, one cannot avoid avoiding, il faut, il ne faut pas

PJP.content: untranslatable [re: Le Parjure] resists passage across frontiers of a nation

PSSS.content: is Derrida or the French language to blame for the untranslatable: avoir mal, faire mal, vouloir du mal, en vouloir à quelqu’un?

PPT.content: the “interest,” the revenue of the surplus value, remains untranslatable in idiom’s economic performance, in ellipses of its trait, the word by word or trait for trait in which it contracts

TN.content: [Derrida’s universality]: convey to “every man’s” ear that world of each person is untranslatable, that there’s never the “same world” > not incompatible premises, condition/call for one another [deconstruction Merleau-Ponty]

AD.content: “face” as untranslatable proper name—by virtue of an event of translation

[re: visages] an other translation, more than a very old name, a poem composing a new accord, an other thought of translation, language unheard of by other man, other of man, other than man [übermensch?]
to say à-Dieu to the face: call the name by name
[other translation] Levinas: “to seek a translation that the properly religious surplus of truth already presupposes”

WOG.content: impossibility to read/translate Greek means those works can’t close upon themselves, already marked by irruption of other [an experience already there for the “original” Greeks]

BSi.content: [re: bêtise as stupidity] the remainder/remnant is untranslated/untranslatable: totality of idiomatic network that coordinates values, quasi-synonymies, homonymies (i.e. bêtise and bête)
but also: point d’intraduisibilité (point of untranslatability, no untranslatability [at all]): no pure translation or untranslation (I can spend a page explaining what can’t be translated)

the untranslatability of bêtise (no word in world can translate it), even untranslatable from French into French > those who speak French, those privileged by the idiom, are commanded by complicated programs, contexts, pragmatic situations > privilege to unique event of language, the “poetic,” is contaminated by reactive or reactional animality [animal-machine]

EU.content: challenge to translation of series Bild, bilden, Bildung (image, form, formation, culture); translation of Übersetzung loses positional dimension of setzen

locate untranslatable nodes in Kant’s The Conflict…, that which doesn’t reach us, remains outside usage of our era > but, rather than simply take inventory of what no longer is, or of certain contradictions—treat the un-translatable experience in excess of dialectical rationality: as a signal that university [since its origin] can’t comprehend [translate] itself in purity of its inside

CHOR.content: poker-like gamble w/ no insurance: “each man and each woman must commit his or her own singularity, the untranslatable factor of his or her life and death”
